<td>

column1: The Tayside Institute for Health Studies leads the contribution of University of Abertay Dundee in relation to education, research and consultancy in health care. The Institute is a Division within the School of Social and Health Sciences, as well as operating as a focal point for co-ordinating developments in health-related studies in other Divisions and Schools within the University.

Tayside Institute for Health Studies is committed to promoting interdisciplinary and inter-professional ways of working, and to the development of pathways for facilitating lifelong learning in healthcare practitioners. The core staff of the Institute represent a range of health professions: nursing, mental health, pharmacology, psychology and counselling.
As well as full undergraduate and postgraduate degree programmes, TIHS also offers a wide range of Continuing Professional Development courses.
The research activity of the Tayside Institute for Health Studies focuses on:

Research currently in progress includes studies of nurse education, wound care, childhood enuresis, history of mental illness, user perspectives on mental health care, health care informatics, use of e-learning, stress and burnout, and the role of counselling in healthcare. The research philosophy of the Institute emphasises the value of practitioner research - there are more than 30 healthcare practitioners undertaking Masters or Doctoral research into aspects of their practice.
BA Nursing Studies

This full or part time course is primarily designed for registered nurses who have completed the 1992 scheme of registration and have attained 60 degree level credit points, although nurses who completed their training before the 1992 scheme was introduced are also welcome. The course is designed to enable students to examine critically and to evaluate nursing practice within contemporary society, examining changes within healthcare that have significance for the role of the nurse. Students also have the opportunity to focus on areas of particular clinical interest.

A thorough grounding in research processes is included, enabling students to utilise current concepts such as research and evidence-based practice. At Honours level, students complete a research project that concentrates on an area in which they have particular interest. In addition to the vocational subject areas offered, students also undergo training in IT, study skills and the use of a modern digitised library.

The degree year is offered on a full and part time basis. Students studying part time can complete the BA degree in one year. Students studying full time can complete the degree in six months. Students studying part time attend University on Wednesdays and complete their five core modules and five options over semesters one and two. Students studying full time also attend on either Tuesday or Wednesdays to complete core modules, plus an additional day, depending on the options chosen.
BA Nursing Studies (with Specialist Practitioner Qualification)

This programme is offered on both a full time and a part time basis. The full time mode is thirty-two weeks duration using an integrated approach. Students are required to attend the University two days a week, undertake two days placement each week and have a further study day. The Public Health (with School Nursing) pathway takes forty weeks full-time study from September to August each year. All the pathways can be studies part-time. Applicants should contact the programme tutor for more information on this mode of study.

The University has been offering high quality nursing education for over 25 years. This course gives you the opportunity to draw on the wealth of experience and expertise that we have developed over these years, and to gain both a degree and professional registration whilst doing so.

The first year of the degree is a common foundation programme, which offers a basic introduction to health and nursing. On successful completion of this part of the course, students may elect to specialise in either adult nursing, or subject to numbers, mental health nursing.

The overall programme of study is designed to equip you with the skills and theoretical knowledge required to practice as a nurse in the 21st Century. To this end we place equal weight on classroom teaching and on clinical practice.
MSc/PGDip Counselling and Health

This course is designed to focus on the training needs and counselling issues faced by health workers, and offers a unique opportunity for practitioners in areas such as medicine, nursing, occupational therapy, occupational health, physiotherapy, complementary medicine, and health promotion to develop their knowledge, skills and competence in counselling. The course is also relevant to counselling and health psychologists, and to specialist counsellors in primary care.

The course emphasises a research-informed, conversational and relational approach to counselling. Successful completion of the course can contribute toward the achievement of professional accreditation as a counsellor. Opportunities exist for those who complete the MSc to continue to Doctoral studies in this area.

column3: (Full-time and part-time)

column1: The Postgraduate Certificate/Diploma/MSc in Counselling Studies programme is designed to meet the counselling training needs of two groups of potential students:

(i) Experienced counselling practitioners who have studied to Postgraduate Certificate/Diploma level develop their knowledge, skills and competence in counselling by completing advanced studies at MSc level. These entrants will normally receive accreditation of prior learning in respect of their previous studies.

(ii) Recent graduates of psychology, behavioural science or social science who seek to undertake advanced study to prepare them for entry to subsequent professional training in counselling, clinical psychology and allied occupations.

The MSc in Counselling Studies programme comprises a wide range of modules in counselling skills and theory, practice, and personal development. There are opportunities to take modules in relevant areas of psychology, sociology and health studies, and to gain credits through work-based learning experiences. Course members are encouraged to negotiate a portfolio of modules designed to achieve their personal learning objectives.

The course emphasises a research-informed, conversational and relational approach to counselling. Successful completion of the course can contribute toward the achievement of professional accreditation as a counsellor. Opportunities exist for those who complete the MSc to continue to Doctoral studies in this area.

column2: (Part time and full time)">MSc/PGDip/PGCert Multicultural Counselling
column3: (Part time and full time)

column1: This course focuses on counselling issues and opportunities associated with the multicultural nature of contemporary societies. The majority of mainstream approaches to counselling are grounded in a set of predominantly monocultural, Western Judeo-Christian assumptions about self, relationships, values and healing. There is a growing realisation within the counselling profession that these assumptions limit the effectiveness of counselling in many situations.

The Postgraduate Certificate/Diploma/MSc in Multicultural Counselling offers a unique opportunity for practitioners of counselling, and members of allied professions such as medicine, nursing, occupational therapy, social work, teaching and the ministry to develop their knowledge, skills and competence in multicultural counselling. The course is particularly appropriate for people working in cross-cultural settings or in non-European countries.

The course emphasises a research-informed, conversational and relational approach to counselling. Successful completion of the course can contribute toward the achievement of professional accreditation as a counsellor. Opportunities exist for those who complete the MSc to continue to Doctoral studies in this area.

column2: title=Graduate Certificate in Counselling Skills">Graduate Certificate in Counselling Skills

column1: The Graduate Certificate in Counselling Skills is designed to offer high-quality skills and personal development opportunities to those using counselling approaches and ideas in a wide variety of settings: health, education, the Church, criminal justice, human resource management, and the voluntary sector.

These part time courses have been especially designed to develop innovative and autonomous practitioners, able to take a leading part in the development and expansion of the nurse's role within the multidisciplinary healthcare team, at a time of unprecedented change within the NHS. Students are encouraged to evaluate and question existing practice in a critical way. The emphasis is on promoting research awareness and evidence-based practice through reflection and advanced study of key professional issues for nurses and midwives.

For the PGDip students are required to develop a research proposal, which is undertaken as a project for the MSc dissertation. Other modules explore issues in counselling, ethics, management and clinical topics such as pain management and chronic wound management. Professionals from a management or educational background may prefer to undertake the health studies branch which is more generic than the named pathways. Advice on course selection is given both through informal visits to the School and at interview. Our aim is to promote excellence in practice, education and research.
We are also developing a number of new courses. Bookmark this page and come back soon for more details:
BA Mental Health and Counselling (course for 2004/5)
